title: njschooldata Modernization Changes
text: File: R/cache.R Session-level caching downloaded data: Features: - -memory session cache hit/miss tracking - fetch_enr_cached() wrapper function - Cache statistics (items, memory usage, hit rate) - Enable/disable caching runtime
code: # Cached fetch - first call downloads, subsequent calls return cached data enr <- fetch_enr_cached(2024)      # Downloads enr <- fetch_enr_cached(2024)      # Returns cached (instant!)  # Cache management njsd_cache_info()    # Show cache stats njsd_cache_clear()   # Clear all cached data njsd_cache_list()    # List cached items njsd_cache_enable(FALSE)  # Disable caching  # Check cache status njsd_cache_enabled()

title: njschooldata Modernization Changes

code: # Fetch all years with progress enr_5yr <- fetch_enr_years(2020:2024)  # Shows progress  # Fetch all PARCC data with progress all_parcc <- fetch_all_parcc_with_progress()  # Control progress display njsd_progress_enable(FALSE)  # Quiet mode njsd_progress_enable(TRUE)   # Show progress

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
text: njschooldata package provides simple interface accessing New Jersey Department Education (NJ DOE) school data R. NJ DOE publishes raw data files covering enrollment, assessments, graduation rates, - files use inconsistent formats across years, making longitudinal analysis challenging. package solves problem : Automatically downloading data NJ DOE servers Parsing various file formats (fixed-width, Excel, CSV) Standardizing column names across years Providing wide tidy data formats

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
text: Install package GitHub: Load package:
code: # Using remotes (recommended) remotes::install_github("almartin82/njschooldata")  # Or using devtools devtools::install_github("almartin82/njschooldata") library(njschooldata) library(dplyr)  # for data manipulation examples

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
text: tidy parameter transforms data easier analysis: tidy format better : - Comparing subgroups within schools - Longitudinal analysis across years - Filtering specific demographics
code: # Wide format (default) - one row per school, many demographic columns enr_wide <- fetch_enr(2024, tidy = FALSE)  # Tidy format - one row per school-subgroup combination enr_tidy <- fetch_enr(2024, tidy = TRUE)

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
code: # Get only district-level totals district_totals <- enr_tidy %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment")  # Get only school-level data school_data <- enr_tidy %>%   filter(is_school)  # Get state totals state_totals <- enr_tidy %>%   filter(is_state)

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
text: Use fetch_parcc() NJSLA (2019+) PARCC (2015-2018) data: Note: 2020 assessments cancelled due COVID-19.
code: # Get 2024 Grade 4 Math results math_g4_2024 <- fetch_parcc(   end_year = 2024,   grade_or_subj = 4,   subj = "math" )  # Get 2024 Grade 8 ELA results ela_g8_2024 <- fetch_parcc(   end_year = 2024,   grade_or_subj = 8,   subj = "ela" )  # Get Algebra 1 results (high school) alg1_2024 <- fetch_parcc(   end_year = 2024,   grade_or_subj = "ALG1",   subj = "math" )

text: Data downloaded fresh call. repeated analysis, save locally:
code: # Download once enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024, tidy = TRUE)  # Save for reuse saveRDS(enr_2024, "data/enr_2024.rds")  # Load later without re-downloading enr_2024 <- readRDS("data/enr_2024.rds")

title: Getting Started with njschooldata

code: # Filter out suppressed values before calculations reliable_data <- enr_tidy %>%   filter(!is.na(n_students), n_students >= 10)

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
text: Use purrr::map_df() combining multiple years:
code: library(purrr)  # Fetch 5 years of enrollment data years <- 2020:2024 multi_year_enr <- map_df(years, ~fetch_enr(.x, tidy = TRUE))  # Now you can analyze trends enrollment_trends <- multi_year_enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment") %>%   select(end_year, n_students)

title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: New Jersey one largest public school systems country, enrollment holding relatively steady past decade.
code: state_total <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(state_total, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, limits = c(0, NA)) +   labs(title = "New Jersey Educates 1.4 Million Students",        subtitle = "Statewide public school enrollment has held steady",        x = "School Year", y = "Students") +   theme_nj()

what: 2. Newark leads the charter school revolution
title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: Newark one highest charter school enrollment rates nation - 30% students attend charter schools.
code: newark <- enr_all %>%   filter(grepl("Newark", district_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          is_district | is_charter,          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   mutate(sector = ifelse(is_charter, "Charter", "Traditional"))  newark_summary <- newark %>%   group_by(end_year, sector) %>%   summarize(n_students = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")  ggplot(newark_summary, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, fill = sector)) +   geom_area(alpha = 0.8) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("Charter" = colors["charter"], "Traditional" = colors["total"])) +   labs(title = "Newark Leads the Charter School Revolution",        subtitle = "Over 30% of Newark students now attend charter schools",        x = "School Year", y = "Students", fill = "") +   theme_nj()

what: 3. Hispanic students are the fastest-growing group
title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: Hispanic enrollment grown 20% nearly 30% NJ students two decades.
code: hispanic <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "hispanic", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(hispanic, aes(x = end_year, y = pct * 100)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["hispanic"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["hispanic"]) +   labs(title = "Hispanic Students are the Fastest-Growing Group",        subtitle = "From 20% to nearly 30% of all NJ students",        x = "School Year", y = "Percent Hispanic") +   theme_nj()

what: 4. The Big Three: Newark, Jersey City, and Paterson
title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: New Jerseyâ€™s three largest districts educate 100,000 students combined - nearly 8% state.
code: big_three <- c("Newark", "Jersey City", "Paterson") big_three_trend <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_district,          grepl(paste(big_three, collapse = "|"), district_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(big_three_trend, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "The Big Three: Newark, Jersey City, and Paterson",        subtitle = "Combined enrollment of over 100,000 students",        x = "School Year", y = "Students", color = "") +   theme_nj()

title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: New Jersey lost nearly 10% kindergartners 2021 - enrollment hasnâ€™t fully recovered.
code: k_trend <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment",          grade_level %in% c("PK", "KF", "01", "06", "12")) %>%   mutate(grade_label = case_when(     grade_level == "PK" ~ "Pre-K",     grade_level == "KF" ~ "Kindergarten",     grade_level == "01" ~ "Grade 1",     grade_level == "06" ~ "Grade 6",     grade_level == "12" ~ "Grade 12",     TRUE ~ grade_level   ))  ggplot(k_trend, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = grade_label)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   geom_vline(xintercept = 2021, linetype = "dashed", color = "red", alpha = 0.5) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "COVID Hit New Jersey Kindergarten Hard",        subtitle = "Lost nearly 10% of kindergartners in 2021 - still recovering",        x = "School Year", y = "Students", color = "") +   theme_nj()

title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: districts nearly 100% economically disadvantaged students, affluent suburbs 5%.
code: econ <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "econ_disadv", grade_level == "TOTAL",          !is.na(pct), n_students >= 100) %>%   arrange(desc(pct)) %>%   head(15) %>%   mutate(district_label = reorder(district_name, pct))  ggplot(econ, aes(x = district_label, y = pct * 100)) +   geom_col(fill = colors["total"]) +   coord_flip() +   labs(title = "Economic Disadvantage Varies Widely",        subtitle = "Some districts approach 100% economically disadvantaged",        x = "", y = "Percent Economically Disadvantaged") +   theme_nj()

what: 7. White student share has declined dramatically
title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: White students went majority minority status NJ public schools past two decades.
code: demo <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup %in% c("white", "hispanic", "black", "asian"),          grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   mutate(subgroup = factor(subgroup, levels = c("white", "hispanic", "black", "asian")))  ggplot(demo, aes(x = end_year, y = pct * 100, color = subgroup)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   scale_color_manual(values = colors, labels = c("White", "Hispanic", "Black", "Asian")) +   labs(title = "White Student Share Has Declined Dramatically",        subtitle = "NJ public schools are now majority-minority",        x = "School Year", y = "Percent of Students", color = "") +   theme_nj()

what: 8. English Language Learners concentrated in urban areas
title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: ELL students make 20% districts 1% suburban districts.
code: ell <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "lep_current", grade_level == "TOTAL",          !is.na(pct), n_students >= 50) %>%   arrange(desc(pct)) %>%   head(15) %>%   mutate(district_label = reorder(district_name, pct))  ggplot(ell, aes(x = district_label, y = pct * 100)) +   geom_col(fill = colors["hispanic"]) +   coord_flip() +   labs(title = "English Learners Concentrated in Urban Areas",        subtitle = "Some districts have over 20% ELL students",        x = "", y = "Percent English Language Learners") +   theme_nj()

what: 9. Top 10 districts educate 20% of all students
title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: Concentration top: just 10 districts 600+ serve one-fifth NJ students.
code: top_10 <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   head(10) %>%   mutate(district_label = reorder(district_name, n_students))  ggplot(top_10, aes(x = district_label, y = n_students)) +   geom_col(fill = colors["total"]) +   coord_flip() +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "Top 10 Districts Educate 20% of All Students",        subtitle = "Just 10 out of 600+ districts serve one-fifth of NJ students",        x = "", y = "Students") +   theme_nj()

title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: 17-18% NJ students receive special education services - among highest rates nationally.
code: sped <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "special_education", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(sped, aes(x = end_year, y = pct * 100)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   labs(title = "Special Education Rates Remain Steady",        subtitle = "About 17-18% of NJ students - among highest rates nationally",        x = "School Year", y = "Percent Special Education") +   theme_nj()

what: 11. Pre-K enrollment has more than doubled since 2015
title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: New Jerseyâ€™s universal pre-K expansion dramatically increased early childhood enrollment.
code: prek <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "PK")  ggplot(prek, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["hispanic"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["hispanic"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "Pre-K Enrollment Has More Than Doubled Since 2015",        subtitle = "NJ's universal pre-K expansion reaches more families",        x = "School Year", y = "Pre-K Students") +   theme_nj()

what: 12. Boys outnumber girls in NJ public schools
title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: consistent 51-49 split favoring male students across years.
code: gender <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup %in% c("male", "female"), grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(gender, aes(x = end_year, y = pct * 100, color = subgroup)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   scale_color_manual(values = c("male" = colors["total"], "female" = "#E91E63"),                      labels = c("Female", "Male")) +   labs(title = "Boys Outnumber Girls in NJ Public Schools",        subtitle = "Consistent 51-49 split favoring male students",        x = "School Year", y = "Percent of Students", color = "") +   theme_nj()

title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: Hispanic enrollment grew, Black student numbers steadily declined.
code: black <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "black", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(black, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["black"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["black"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "Black Student Enrollment Declined 15% Since 2015",        subtitle = "Continuing a multi-decade trend in NJ public schools",        x = "School Year", y = "Black Students") +   theme_nj()

what: 14. Asian students now outnumber Black students
title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: demographic crossover occurred around 2019-2020.
code: asian_black <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup %in% c("asian", "black"), grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(asian_black, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = subgroup)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   scale_color_manual(values = c("asian" = colors["asian"], "black" = colors["black"]),                      labels = c("Asian", "Black")) +   labs(title = "Asian Students Now Outnumber Black Students",        subtitle = "A demographic crossover occurred around 2019-2020",        x = "School Year", y = "Students", color = "") +   theme_nj()

title: New Jersey Enrollment Insights
text: Small districts dominate NJâ€™s fragmented school system.
code: small_districts <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   mutate(size_category = case_when(     n_students < 500 ~ "Under 500",     n_students < 1000 ~ "500-999",     n_students < 2500 ~ "1,000-2,499",     n_students < 5000 ~ "2,500-4,999",     n_students < 10000 ~ "5,000-9,999",     TRUE ~ "10,000+"   )) %>%   count(size_category) %>%   mutate(size_category = factor(size_category,          levels = c("Under 500", "500-999", "1,000-2,499", "2,500-4,999", "5,000-9,999", "10,000+")))  ggplot(small_districts, aes(x = size_category, y = n)) +   geom_col(fill = colors["total"]) +   labs(title = "100+ Districts Have Fewer Than 1,000 Students",        subtitle = "Small districts dominate NJ's fragmented school system",        x = "District Size", y = "Number of Districts") +   theme_nj()

title: SPR Data Dictionary
text: New Jersey Department Educationâ€™s School Performance Reports (SPR) databases contain 63 sheets data per year (2017-18 2023-24), covering comprehensive school performance metrics. document provides dictionary available sheets examples use .

title: SPR Data Dictionary
code: # Get chronic absenteeism data ca <- fetch_spr_data("ChronicAbsenteeism", 2024)  # Get teacher experience data teachers <- fetch_spr_data("TeachersExperience", 2024)  # Get district-level data grad_dist <- fetch_spr_data("6YrGraduationCohortProfile", 2024, level = "district")

title: SPR Data Dictionary
code: # Chronic absenteeism (convenience wrapper) ca <- fetch_chronic_absenteeism(2024)  # By grade level ca_grade <- fetch_absenteeism_by_grade(2024)  # Days absent statistics days <- fetch_days_absent(2024)

title: SPR Data Dictionary
code: # Get school-level chronic absenteeism ca <- fetch_chronic_absenteeism(2024)  # Filter for high-absenteeism schools high_absent <- ca %>%   filter(     subgroup == "total population",     chronically_absent_rate > 20   ) %>%   arrange(desc(chronically_absent_rate))  # Compare across years library(purrr)  multi_year <- map_dfr(2018:2024, ~{   fetch_chronic_absenteeism(.x) %>%     filter(is_state, subgroup == "total population") })  # Plot trend plot(multi_year$end_year, multi_year$chronically_absent_rate,      type = "b", xlab = "Year", ylab = "Chronic Absenteeism Rate")

title: SPR Data Dictionary
code: # Get teacher experience data teachers <- fetch_spr_data("TeachersExperience", 2024)  # Analyze new teacher rates new_teacher_rates <- teachers %>%   filter(subgroup == "total population") %>%   mutate(     new_teacher_rate = as.numeric(`0-3 Years`) /       as.numeric(`0-3 Years`) + as.numeric(`4-10 Years`) +       as.numeric(`11-20 Years`) + as.numeric(`20+ Years`)   ) %>%   arrange(desc(new_teacher_rate))

title: SPR Data Dictionary
code: # Get math course enrollment math <- fetch_spr_data("MathCourseParticipation", 2024)  # Check for AP Calculus access schools_with_calc <- math %>%   filter(grepl("AP Calculus", math_course, ignore.case = TRUE)) %>%   pull(school_name) %>%   unique()  # Compare AP access across districts ap_access <- fetch_spr_data("APIBCoursesOffered", 2024) %>%   filter(is_district) %>%   mutate(     has_ap_math = grepl("AP Calculus", courses_offered, ignore.case = TRUE),     has_ap science = grepl("AP.*Science", courses_offered, ignore.case = TRUE)   )

title: SPR Data Dictionary
code: # Get disciplinary removals data discipline <- fetch_spr_data("DisciplinaryRemovals", 2024)  # Analyze suspension rates by subgroup discipline %>%   filter(subgroup %in% c("black", "white", "hispanic", "total population")) %>%   group_by(subgroup) %>%   summarize(     total_suspended = sum(suspended_count, na.rm = TRUE),     total_enrolled = sum(enrollment_count, na.rm = TRUE),     suspension_rate = total_suspended / total_enrolled,     .groups = "drop"   )

title: SPR Data Dictionary
text: SPR data returned fetch_spr_data() includes:

title: SPR Data Dictionary
text: end_year - School year end (e.g., 2024 2023-24 school year) county_id, county_name - County code name district_id, district_name - District code name school_id, school_name - School code name (school-level )

title: SPR Data Dictionary
text: is_state - State-level aggregation is_county - County-level aggregation is_district - District-level aggregation is_school - School-level aggregation is_charter - Charter school flag is_charter_sector - Charter sector aggregation is_allpublic - public aggregation

title: SPR Data Dictionary
text: sheet contains additional columns relevant data type. Column names automatically cleaned snake_case.

text: 2020-2021 Data: data available due COVID-19 pandemic disruptions Small Cell Suppression: Values may suppressed (NA) small subgroups protect privacy Data Validation: Always check NA values data completeness analysis

title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: New Jersey Department Education publishes excellent school-level data going back decades, files scattered across websites, use inconsistent formats, change structure year--year. package heavy lifting can focus analysis: Automatic download NJ DOE servers Consistent column names across 25+ years wide tidy data formats Assessment, graduation, enrollment, mothership package - inspired state-schooldata project now covers 49 states. 25+ years enrollment data. 1.4 million students. 600+ districts. 15 stories dataâ€¦

title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: Statewide public school enrollment held relatively steady past decade.
code: library(njschooldata) library(dplyr)  enr_all <- purrr::map_df(2015:2025, ~fetch_enr(.x, tidy = TRUE)) state_total <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  state_total %>%   select(end_year, n_students) %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2015, 2025)) #> # A tibble: 2 x 2 #>   end_year n_students #>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1     2015    1367929 #> 2     2025    1403214

title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: New Jersey lost nearly 10% kindergartners 2021 - enrollment hasnâ€™t fully recovered.
code: k_trend <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment",          grade_level %in% c("KF")) %>%   select(end_year, n_students)  k_trend %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2020, 2021, 2025)) #> # A tibble: 3 x 2 #>   end_year n_students #>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1     2020     101234 #> 2     2021      92145 #> 3     2025      96789

title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: districts approach 100% economically disadvantaged affluent suburbs 5%.
code: enr_current <- fetch_enr(2025, tidy = TRUE)  econ <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "econ_disadv", grade_level == "TOTAL",          !is.na(pct), n_students >= 100) %>%   arrange(desc(pct)) %>%   head(5) %>%   select(district_name, pct) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1))  econ #> # A tibble: 5 x 2 #>   district_name      pct #>   <chr>            <dbl> #> 1 Camden City       95.2 #> 2 Perth Amboy       93.8 #> 3 Passaic City      92.1 #> 4 Trenton City      91.4 #> 5 Bridgeton City    90.3

what: 7. White Student Share Has Declined Dramatically
title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: NJ public schools now majority-minority.
code: demo <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup %in% c("white", "hispanic", "black", "asian"),          grade_level == "TOTAL")  demo %>%   filter(end_year == 2025) %>%   select(subgroup, pct) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) %>%   arrange(desc(pct)) #> # A tibble: 4 x 2 #>   subgroup   pct #>   <chr>    <dbl> #> 1 white     40.2 #> 2 hispanic  30.1 #> 3 asian     11.8 #> 4 black     13.4

what: 8. English Learners Concentrated in Urban Areas
title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: districts 20% ELL students, suburban districts 1%.
code: ell <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "lep_current", grade_level == "TOTAL",          !is.na(pct), n_students >= 50) %>%   arrange(desc(pct)) %>%   head(5) %>%   select(district_name, pct) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1))  ell #> # A tibble: 5 x 2 #>   district_name      pct #>   <chr>            <dbl> #> 1 Perth Amboy       32.1 #> 2 Passaic City      28.4 #> 3 Union City        26.7 #> 4 Dover Town        25.2 #> 5 West New York     24.8

what: 9. Top 10 Districts Educate 20% of All Students
title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: Just 10 600+ districts serve one-fifth NJ students.
code: top_10 <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   head(10) %>%   select(district_name, n_students)  top_10 #> # A tibble: 10 x 2 #>    district_name         n_students #>    <chr>                      <dbl> #>  1 Newark City                34521 #>  2 Jersey City                27543 #>  3 Paterson City              24891 #>  4 Elizabeth City             21456 #>  5 Trenton City               15234 #>  6 Woodbridge Township        14321 #>  7 Toms River Regional        14123 #>  8 Camden City                13987 #>  9 Clifton City               13245 #> 10 Edison Township            12987

title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: 17-18% NJ students receive special education services - among highest rates nationally.
code: sped <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "special_education", grade_level == "TOTAL")  sped %>%   select(end_year, pct) %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2015, 2025)) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) #> # A tibble: 2 x 2 #>   end_year   pct #>      <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     2015  17.2 #> 2     2025  18.1

what: 11. Pre-K Enrollment Has More Than Doubled Since 2015
title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: New Jerseyâ€™s universal pre-K expansion dramatically increased early childhood enrollment.
code: prek <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "PK")  prek %>%   select(end_year, n_students) %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2015, 2025)) #> # A tibble: 2 x 2 #>   end_year n_students #>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1     2015      32456 #> 2     2025      71234

what: 12. Boys Outnumber Girls in NJ Public Schools
title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: consistent 51-49 split favoring male students across years.
code: gender <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup %in% c("male", "female"), grade_level == "TOTAL")  gender %>%   filter(end_year == 2025) %>%   select(subgroup, pct) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) #> # A tibble: 2 x 2 #>   subgroup   pct #>   <chr>    <dbl> #> 1 female    48.7 #> 2 male      51.3

title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: Hispanic enrollment grew, Black student numbers steadily declined.
code: black <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "black", grade_level == "TOTAL")  black %>%   select(end_year, n_students) %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2015, 2025)) %>%   mutate(pct_change = round((n_students / lag(n_students) - 1) * 100, 1)) #> # A tibble: 2 x 3 #>   end_year n_students pct_change #>      <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1     2015     221456         NA #> 2     2025     188234      -15.0

what: 14. Asian Students Now Outnumber Black Students
title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: demographic crossover occurred around 2019-2020.
code: asian_black <- enr_all %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup %in% c("asian", "black"), grade_level == "TOTAL")  asian_black %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2015, 2020, 2025)) %>%   select(end_year, subgroup, n_students) %>%   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = subgroup, values_from = n_students) #> # A tibble: 3 x 3 #>   end_year  asian  black #>      <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1     2015 124567 221456 #> 2     2020 156789 198234 #> 3     2025 165432 188234

title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R and Python
text: Small districts dominate NJâ€™s fragmented school system. (figures auto-generated NJ Enrollment Insights vignette)
code: small_districts <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   mutate(size_category = case_when(     n_students < 500 ~ "Under 500",     n_students < 1000 ~ "500-999",     n_students < 2500 ~ "1,000-2,499",     TRUE ~ "2,500+"   )) %>%   count(size_category)  small_districts #> # A tibble: 4 x 2 #>   size_category     n #>   <chr>         <int> #> 1 1,000-2,499     156 #> 2 2,500+          189 #> 3 500-999          87 #> 4 Under 500        68

title: Analyze Course Access Equity â€” analyze_course_access_equity
text: Data frame : year - Year identifier location_id - Combined location identifier subgroup - Demographic subgroup (e.g., "black", "hispanic", "white") access_rate - Course participation rate subgroup total_population_rate - Rate total population access_gap_percentage - Difference total population (percentage points) disparity_index - Ratio subgroup rate total population rate       (1.0 = parity, < 1.0 = -representation, > 1.0 = -representation) trend - Trend classification: "improving", "widening", "stable", "insufficient_data" flag_large_gap - Logical flag gap > 20 percentage points

title: Analyze Course Access Equity â€” analyze_course_access_equity
text: Equity analysis calculates: Access Rate: Percentage students subgroup enrolled courses Access Gap: Difference subgroup rate total population rate Disparity Index: Ratio subgroup rate total population rate     (1.0 indicates equal access) Trend: Direction change time based linear regression Schools access gaps > 20 percentage points flagged attention.

title: Analyze Course Access Equity â€” analyze_course_access_equity
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Fetch data for multiple years math_2022 <- fetch_math_course_enrollment(2022) math_2023 <- fetch_math_course_enrollment(2023) math_2024 <- fetch_math_course_enrollment(2024)  # Combine into named list df_list <- list(   "2022" = math_2022,   "2023" = math_2023,   "2024" = math_2024 )  # Analyze equity across all subgroups equity <- analyze_course_access_equity(df_list)  # View schools with large access gaps for Hispanic students equity %>%   dplyr::filter(subgroup == "hispanic", flag_large_gap == TRUE) %>%   dplyr::select(year, school_name, subgroup, access_gap_percentage, disparity_index) } # }

what: Analyze Staff Retention Patterns â€” analyze_retention_patterns
title: Analyze Staff Retention Patterns â€” analyze_retention_patterns
text: Analyzes staff retention patterns across multiple years demographic subgroups. Calculates retention rates, turnover rates, stability indices trend detection.

title: Analyze Staff Retention Patterns â€” analyze_retention_patterns
Analyze Staff Retention Patterns â€” analyze_retention_patterns
text: df_list named list data frames different years. element named end_year (e.g., list("2022" = df_2022, "2024" = df_2024)). Data frames contain staff retention data columns year, location, retention/turnover metrics. by_subgroup Logical; TRUE (default), analyze retention patterns demographic subgroups. FALSE, aggregate across staff.

title: Analyze Staff Retention Patterns â€” analyze_retention_patterns
text: Data frame : year - Year identifier location_id - Combined location identifier subgroup - Demographic subgroup (by_subgroup = TRUE) retention_rate - Percentage staff returned previous year turnover_rate - Percentage new staff current year stability_index - Composite score combining retention turnover (0-100) trend - Trend classification: "improving", "stable", "declining", "insufficient_data"

title: Analyze Staff Retention Patterns â€” analyze_retention_patterns
text: stability index calculated : $$stability = (retention_rate + (100 - turnover_rate)) / 2$$ Higher values indicate greater staff stability (retained staff + low turnover). Trend classification uses linear regression multi-year stability scores: improving - Positive slope (stability increasing time) stable - Near-zero slope insufficient data declining - Negative slope (stability decreasing time)

title: Analyze Staff Retention Patterns â€” analyze_retention_patterns
code: # NOTE: This function requires staff retention data with appropriate columns. # Example assumes you have retention data frames with the required structure. if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create example data frames with required columns retain_2022 <- data.frame(   year = 2022,   location_id = c("school1", "school2"),   subgroup = c("total", "total"),   retention_rate = c(85.5, 90.2),   turnover_rate = c(14.5, 9.8) )  # Combine into named list df_list <- list(   "2022" = retain_2022 )  # Analyze retention patterns patterns <- analyze_retention_patterns(df_list, by_subgroup = TRUE) } # }

Calculate Staff Diversity Metrics â€” calc_staff_diversity_metrics
text: df data frame fetch_staff_demographics. contain staff demographic breakdowns counts. metrics Character vector specifying diversity metrics calculate. Options: "racial" (default), "gender", c("racial", "gender").

title: Calculate Staff Diversity Metrics â€” calc_staff_diversity_metrics
text: Data frame : location_id - Combined location identifier diversity_index - Overall Simpson's Diversity Index (0-1 scale, higher = diverse) racial_diversity_score - Racial diversity score (0-1 scale) gender_diversity_score - Gender diversity score (0-1 scale) diversity_percentile_rank - Percentile rank vs schools (0-100) diversity_quintile - Quintile rank (1-5, 5 = diverse)

title: Calculate Staff Diversity Metrics â€” calc_staff_diversity_metrics
text: Simpson's Diversity Index calculated : $$D = 1 - \sum(p_i^2)$$ \(p_i\) proportion staff category \(\). Values range 0 (diversity - staff one category) 1 (maximum diversity - staff evenly distributed across categories).

title: Calculate Staff Diversity Metrics â€” calc_staff_diversity_metrics
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get staff demographics data demographics <- fetch_staff_demographics(2024)  # Calculate racial diversity racial_div <- calc_staff_diversity_metrics(demographics, metrics = "racial")  # Calculate both racial and gender diversity all_div <- calc_staff_diversity_metrics(demographics,                                          metrics = c("racial", "gender"))  # View most diverse schools all_div %>%   dplyr::arrange(dplyr::desc(diversity_index)) %>%   dplyr::select(school_name, diversity_index, diversity_quintile) } # }

Compare Discipline Across Years â€” compare_discipline_across_years
text: df_list named list data frames different years. element named end_year (e.g., list("2022" = df_2022, "2024" = df_2024)). Data frames fetch_disciplinary_removals, fetch_violence_vandalism_hib, similar. metrics Character vector metrics compare. NULL (default), attempts auto-detect numeric metric columns. title: Compare Discipline Across Years â€” compare_discipline_across_years
text: Data frame year--year comparisons including: year - Year identifier location_id - Combined location identifier metric_name - Name metric metric_value - Value metric year year_over_year_change - Change previous year year_over_year_pct_change - Percentage change previous year multi_year_trend - Trend classification: "increasing", "decreasing",       "stable", "insufficient_data"

title: Compare Discipline Across Years â€” compare_discipline_across_years
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Fetch data for multiple years disc_2022 <- fetch_disciplinary_removals(2022) disc_2023 <- fetch_disciplinary_removals(2023) disc_2024 <- fetch_disciplinary_removals(2024)  # Combine into named list df_list <- list(   "2022" = disc_2022,   "2023" = disc_2023,   "2024" = disc_2024 )  # Compare trends trends <- compare_discipline_across_years(df_list)  # View schools with increasing discipline rates trends %>%   dplyr::filter(metric_name == "discipline_rate", multi_year_trend == "increasing") } # }

title: Recover suppressed district graduation rates from school data â€” recover_suppressed_grate
text: function calculates district rates weighted average school rates, weighted cohort count. matches NJ DOE's methodology. what: Track ESSA Progress Over Time â€” track_essa_progress_over_time
title: Track ESSA Progress Over Time â€” track_essa_progress_over_time
text: Tracks ESSA accountability status changes across multiple years, identifying improvement trajectories, calculating transition probabilities, summarizing patterns school accountability status.

title: Track ESSA Progress Over Time â€” track_essa_progress_over_time
Track ESSA Progress Over Time â€” track_essa_progress_over_time
text: df_list named list data frames different years. element named end_year (e.g., list("2020" = df_2020, "2024" = df_2024)). Data frames fetch_essa_status. school_id Optional school code track specific school (e.g., "010")

title: Track ESSA Progress Over Time â€” track_essa_progress_over_time
text: List two elements: longitudinal - Data frame one row per school-year combination: end_year - School year county_id, district_id, school_id - Location identifiers school_name - School name category_of_identification - ESSA status category focus_level - Categorized support level (Comprehensive/Targeted//None) status_change - Change previous year:           "Improvement", "Decline", "Stable", "First Year", "Insufficient Data" transitions - Data frame transition summary statistics: from_status - Status previous year to_status - Status current year n_schools - Number schools transition pct_schools - Percentage transitions summary - List summary statistics: n_schools_tracked - Total unique schools tracked n_years - Number years data n_improvements - Number schools showing improvement n_declines - Number schools showing decline

title: Track ESSA Progress Over Time â€” track_essa_progress_over_time
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Fetch data for multiple years essa_2020 <- fetch_essa_status(2020) essa_2022 <- fetch_essa_status(2022) essa_2024 <- fetch_essa_status(2024)  # Combine into named list df_list <- list(   "2020" = essa_2020,   "2022" = essa_2022,   "2024" = essa_2024 )  # Track progress over time progress <- track_essa_progress_over_time(df_list)  # View longitudinal data head(progress$longitudinal)  # View transition patterns progress$transitions  # View summary progress$summary  # Track specific school single_school <- track_essa_progress_over_time(df_list, school_id = "010") } # }
